description:
His name is Guts, the Black Swordsman, a feared warrior spoken of only in whispers. Bearer of a gigantic sword, an iron hand, and the scars of countless battles and tortures, his flesh is also indelibly marked with The Brand, an unholy symbol that draws the forces of darkness to him and dooms him as their sacrifice. But Guts won't take his fate lying down; he'll cut a crimson swath of carnage through the ranks of the damned—and anyone else foolish enough to oppose him! Accompanied by Puck the Elf, more an annoyance than a companion, Guts relentlessly follows a dark, bloodstained path that leads only to death...or vengeance.

(Source: Dark Horse)

Notes:
- Volumes 1-5 contain the 16 prequel chapters 0A - 0P.
- Chapter 83 was omitted from Volume 13 due to the author’s request.
- Volume 14 includes “Berserk: The Prototype”.
- Due to the author's passing, starting from Chapter 365, the manga is illustrated by Studio Gaga (Miura's assistants) and supervised by Kouji Mori (a close friend of Miura's).
synonyms: เบอร์เซิร์ก

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Seinen
tags.description: Target demographic is adult males.

tags.name: Revenge
tags.description: Prominently features a character who aims to exact punishment in a resentful or vindictive manner.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Demons
tags.description: Prominently features malevolent otherworldly creatures.

tags.name: Cosmic Horror
tags.description: A type of horror that emphasizes human insignificance in the grand scope of cosmic reality; fearing the unknown and being powerless to fight it.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Found Family
tags.description: Features a group of characters with no biological relations that are united in a group providing social support.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Rape
tags.description: Features non-consensual sexual penetration.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Rehabilitation
tags.description: Prominently features the recovery of a character who became incapable of social life or work.

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Mythology
tags.description: Prominently features mythological elements, especially those from religious or cultural tradition.

tags.name: Survival
tags.description: Centers around the struggle to live in spite of extreme obstacles.

tags.name: Foreign
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a country outside the country of origin.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Religion
tags.description: Centers on the belief that humanity is related to supernatural, transcendental, and spiritual elements.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Fairy
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a fairy.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Disability
tags.description: A work that features one or more characters with a physical, mental, cognitive, or developmental condition that impairs, interferes with, or limits the person's ability to engage in certain tasks or actions.

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

tags.name: Witch
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a witch.

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Sadism
tags.description: Prominently features characters deriving pleasure, especially sexual gratification, from inflicting pain, suffering, or humiliation on others.

tags.name: Torture
tags.description: The act of deliberately inflicting severe pain or suffering upon another individual or oneself as a punishment or with a specific purpose.

tags.name: Amnesia
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.name: Time Skip
tags.description: Features a gap in time used to advance the story.

tags.name: Elf
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is an elf.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Kaiju
tags.description: Prominently features giant monsters.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Achronological Order
tags.description: Chapters or episodes do not occur in chronological order.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Age Regression
tags.description: Prominently features a character who was returned to a younger state.

tags.name: Skeleton
tags.description: Prominently features skeleton(s) as a character.

tags.name: Cult
tags.description: Features a social group with unorthodox religious, spiritual, or philosophical beliefs and practices.

tags.name: Adoption
tags.description: Features a character who has been adopted by someone who is neither of their biological parents.

tags.name: Dungeon
tags.description: Prominently features a dungeon environment.

tags.name: Slavery
tags.description: Prominently features slaves, slavery, or slave trade.

tags.name: Dragons
tags.description: Prominently features mythical reptiles which generally have wings and can breathe fire.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Kingdom Management
tags.description: Characters in these series take on the responsibility of running a town or kingdom, whether they take control of an existing one, or build their own from the ground up.

tags.name: Group Sex
tags.description: Features more than two participants engaged in sex simultaneously.

tags.name: Prostitution
tags.description: Features characters who are paid for sexual favors.

tags.name: Cannibalism
tags.description: Prominently features the act of consuming another member of the same species as food.

tags.name: Pregnancy
tags.description: Features pregnant female characters or discusses the topic of pregnancy.

tags.name: Incest
tags.description: Features sexual or romantic relations between characters who are related by blood.

tags.name: Curses
tags.description: Features a character, object or area that has been cursed, usually by a malevolent supernatural force.

tags.name: Medieval
tags.description: Partially or completely set in the Middle Ages or a Middle Ages-inspired setting. Commonly features elements such as European castles and knights.

tags.name: Ships
tags.description: Prominently features the use of sea-based transportation vessels.

tags.name: Monster Girl
tags.description: Prominently features a female character who is part-monster.

tags.name: Vore
tags.description: Features a character being swallowed or swallowing another creature whole.

tags.name: Monster Boy
tags.description: Prominently features a male character who is a part-monster.

tags.name: LGBTQ+ Themes
tags.description: Prominently features characters or themes associated with the LGBTQ+ community, such as sexuality or gender identity.

tags.name: Mermaid
tags.description: A mythological creature with the body of a human and the tail of a fish.

tags.name: Masturbation
tags.description: Features erotic stimulation of one's own genitalia or other erogenous regions.

tags.name: Fellatio
tags.description: Blowjob; features oral sex performed on male genitalia.

node.description:
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%B8%89%E6%B5%A6%E5%BB%BA%E5%A4%AA%E9%83%8E) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentaro_Miura)

A Japanese manga artist best known for his popular dark fantasy manga [Berserk](https://anilist.co/manga/30002/), which began serialization in 1989.

At the early age of 10, Miura made his first manga, entitled Miuranger, that was published for his classmates in a school publication; the manga ended up spanning 40 volumes. In 1977, Miura created his second manga called Ken e no michi, using India ink for the first time. When he was in middle school in 1979, Miura's drawing techniques improved greatly as he started using professional drawing techniques. His first doujinshi was published, with the help of friends, in a magazine in 1982.

That same year, in 1982, Miura enrolled in an artistic curriculum in high school, where he and his classmates started publishing their works in school booklets, as well as having his first dōjinshi published in a fan-produced magazine. In 1985, Miura applied for the entrance examination of an art college in Nihon University. He submitted [Futatabi](https://anilist.co/manga/79949/) for examination and was granted admission. This project was later nominated Best New Author work in Weekly Shounen Magazine. Another Miura manga, [Noa](https://anilist.co/manga/92584/), was published in Weekly Shounen Magazine the very same year. Due to a disagreement with one of the editors, the manga was stalled and eventually dropped altogether. This is approximately where Miura's career hit a slump.

In 1988, Miura bounced back with a 48-page manga known as [Berserk Prototype](https://anilist.co/manga/36408/), as an introduction to the current Berserk fantasy world. It went on to win Miura a prize from the Comi Manga School. In 1989 Miura started a project titled [Ourou](https://anilist.co/manga/31043/) based on a script by [Buronson](https://anilist.co/staff/97848/), writer of [Hokuto no Ken](https://anilist.co/manga/31149/). It was published in the Japanese magazine Monthly Animal House in May and July of that year.

In 1990, a sequel is made to Ourou entitled [Ourouden](https://anilist.co/manga/40867/) that was published as a prequel to the original in Young Animal magazine. In the same year, the October issue of Animal House witnesses the first volume of the solo project Berserk was released with a relatively limited success. Miura again collaborated with Buronson on manga titled [Japan](https://anilist.co/manga/30968/), that was published in Young Animal from the 1st issue to the 8th of 1992, and was later released as a stand-alone tankoubon. Miura's fame grew after Berserk was serialized in Young Animal in 1992 with the release of "The Golden Age" story arc and ultimately the series became a huge success, making him one of the most prominent contemporary manga artists. At this time Miura dedicates himself solely to be working on Berserk. He had indicated, however, that he intended to publish more manga in the future.

In 1997, Miura supervised the production of a [25-episode adaptation](https://anilist.co/anime/33/) of Berserk, that aired in the same year on NTV. Various art books and supplemental materials by Miura based on Berserk are also released. In 1999, Miura made contributions to the Dreamcast video game Sword of the Berserk: Guts' Rage including co-writing the story's plot. 2004 saw the release of yet another video game adaptation entitled Berserk Millennium Falcon Arc: Chapter of the Holy Demon War which Miura also helped to write. In 2013, Miura released the standalone manga Gigantomakhia, which was released into English speaking territories as Giganto Maxia by the publisher Dark Horse in 2016.

Since that time, the Berserk manga has spanned 40 tankoubon with no end in sight. The series has also spawned a whole host of merchandise, both official and fan-made, ranging from statues, action figures to key rings, video games, and a trading card game. In 2002, Miura received the second place in the Tezuka Osamu Cultural Prize of Excellence for Berserk.

On May 19, 2021, the Hakusensha editorial department stated that Miura passed away on May 6 due to an acute aortic dissection.

Miura provided the design for the Vocaloid [Gakupo Kamui](https://anilist.co/character/22085/), whose voice is taken from the Japanese singer and actor Gackt.

Dan Nakrosis has penciled, inked, colored or lettered hundreds of kids comics for Archie, Harvey, Disney, Mirage and many more publishers. He co-created  The Conservation Corps for Archie, and has also worked  for DC, Marvel, Dark Horse, First, Malibu, Comico, and basically every major comic company.  He spent a short time as an editor at Image, and then became one of the “go to guys” in the emerging Manga Industry, where he adapted and packaged such well known titles as Pokemon, Beserk, Tenchi Muyo, Batman, Spider-Man and the X-Men, the last two he actually took over the publishing after Marvel had cancelled them. He currently has a new book, The DK Zombify Rock n’ Roll Zombies Coloring Book debuting this summer.

Johnson is a freelance translator. After graduating with a degree in Japanese Studies, Duane suspected he'd never do anything professional with it, until a few years later an opportunity chanced across his path. Leaving a relatively secure IT job behind, he dove head-first into the harrowing world of freelance translation, and has been there ever since. Ten years later, Duane's list of clients includes such names as Digital Manga Publishing, Media Blasters, Tokyopop, and Toei Animation, and he considers himself fortunate to have worked on projects such as the Berserk manga and the Genshiken anime. When he's not busy with translation work or hunting down more of it, he enjoys spending time with his wife and two cats.

An author and translator in Macmillan publishers, Jason DeAngelis is an expert in Japanese language and culture, having lived, worked, and studied martial arts in Japan for six years. Working as a freelance Japanese translator, he has translated such prominent manga titles as Berserk and Gundam Seed. He is also the Chief Creative Officer at Seven Seas, and oversees original manga production.

(Source: MacMillan)
He is a French Translator who has translated famous works like Berserk and Eyeshield 21.

[Website](http://gilles.cyna.fr/)

René-Gilles is a French who also speaks English, reads Japanese and has experience as a journalist, translator and developer of utilities, video games and websites.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/pawel_dybala)
Besides translation, he also does lectures and research at the Jagiellonian University in Kraków. Works with publishers J.P.Fantastica and Egmont Poland.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/taigaofgenesis)

Mori is married to mangaka Akkiu.

He became narrative consultants for Berserk over time as stated in 'Challenging the Manga Dojos' as he was a friend of [Kentarou Miura](https://anilist.co/staff/96868/).

Studio Gaga is a Japanese manga production studio founded by Kentarou Miura. A primary motivation for Miura creating the studio was so that his assistants could be included in his works under an official collective name.

__Current Members:__
• Yoshimitsu Kurosaki (黒崎能光) – volumes 26 and 27; volume 29 and onward
• Akio Miyaji (宮地秋夫) – volume 28 and onward
• Nobuhiro Hirai (平井信周) – volume 28 and onward
• Naohide Nagashima (長島有秀) – volume 29 and onward
• Shigeru Kinoshita (木下滋)
• Hideki Sugimoto (杉本英輝)

__Former Members:__
• Yasushi Hirasawa – volume 7
• Satoru Ohtuka – volumes 7 through 17
• Takashi Uchida – volumes 7 through 28
• Yoshinari Sawada – volumes 8 through 17
• [Mitsuhisa Kuji](https://anilist.co/staff/108901) (久慈光久) – volumes 18 through 26
• Minoru Hirata – volumes 18 through 30; volumes 35 and 36
• Chigusa Amagasaki – volumes 30 through 34

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/marcbernabe) |  [Official Website](https://www.japonesenvinetas.com)

He is a translator and interpreter of Japanese, with special emphasis on the translation of manga and anime, a field in which he has a background of hundreds of volumes and episodes translated. In addition, he's a  specialist in didactics of the Japanese language and culture for Spanish speakers. He also has published many books about Japan and Asia.

He is famous for appearing in a Shin-chan's episode where the family goes to Spain.
